Thank you for focusing on the matter of the small town of Holmdel against the huge Southland Corporation and our yearlong efforts to stop the proposed location of their 7-Eleven store adjacent to the New School of Monmouth County.

The children in this conflict have provided the most sobering viewpoint in this unwieldy process. These children, ranging in from 5 to 14 years old, have gotten a first-hand education in something not usually taught in the classrooms: local politics. Often a confused child would turn to another during the endless testimony and cut to the chase:
''Don't they know there's a school next door? Don't they care about their delivery trucks coming so close to our playground?''

Many good points were presented during these community meetings, pertaining to the loss of property values for adjacent homeowners; the dangers of stop-and-go-traffic on this corner, already notorious for accidents; the undersized dimensions of the proposed parking lot; and the plan of the founding fathers of Holmdel to purposefully keep 24-hour stores out of this peaceful town. But the most touching argument comes from the children, against whose very lives Southland is betting.
